diagnosis.score_headline: Identity Crisis: Luxury Science vs. Commodity Basics
diagnosis.score_summary: The brand is suffering from severe schizophrenia. On WWW, you are a high-end 'Clinical Authority' selling a transformation; on PDP, you are a 'Daily Essential' selling basic hydration. This disconnect erodes pricing power and dilutes the premium claim.

truth_1.headline: Doctor vs. Nanny
truth_1.gap_description: WWW signals 'The Sage' (Authority/Wisdom). PDP signals 'The Caregiver' (Service/Safety). You are trying to be a Doctor on your site and a Nanny on Amazon.
truth_1.why_matters: This is a foundational identity crisis. A 'Sage' commands a premium price for knowledge; a 'Caregiver' is expected to be affordable and accommodating. This gap creates price resistance.
truth_1.the_hard_choice: You are currently projecting conflicting psychological cues—one of dominance (Sage) and one of submission (Caregiver). The market needs to know if you are leading them or serving them. You must choose: either enforce the 'Sage' authority on Amazon to justify the premium (Option A), or soften the website to 'Caregiver' and accept a mass-market positioning (Option B). You cannot command respect while asking for permission.

truth_2.headline: The Personality Disorder
truth_2.gap_description: The WWW personality is 'The Dermatologist'—cool, precise, and distant. The PDP personality is 'The Mommy Blogger'—warm, over-sharing, and eager to please.
truth_2.evidence: WWW: 'The Expert' (Cool/Detached) vs. PDP: 'The Best Friend' (Warm/Chatty)
truth_2.why_matters: Personality drives emotional connection. By swapping personalities across channels, you break the relationship. Customers don't know if they are buying science or sympathy.
truth_2.the_hard_choice: Your brand has a split personality that is confusing the customer. The website is cold and premium; the Amazon page is warm and cheap. You face a strategic ultimatum: either train the Amazon team to speak with the cool detachment of a clinic (Option A), or warm up the website to match the friendly reality of the marketplace (Option B). Warmth sells volume, but Cool sells margin.

truth_3.headline: Patents vs. Texture
truth_3.gap_description: WWW sells the 'Science' (Ingredients/Patents). PDP sells the 'Sensation' (Texture/Feel). You are selling a medical breakthrough on one channel and a cosmetic convenience on the other.
truth_3.why_matters: When the KSPs don't match, the value proposition collapses. The customer sees 'Science' on the site but finds 'Basic Lotion' on Amazon, leading them to believe the science is fake.
truth_3.the_hard_choice: You are trapped between being a biotech company and a lotion factory. The data demands a choice: either force the Amazon listing to lead with the hard science to filter for serious buyers (Option A), or strip the complex claims from the website and sell the sensory experience globally (Option B). A patent is worthless if the customer only cares that it isn't sticky.

truth_4.headline: The Commodity Trap
truth_4.gap_description: Both channels agree heavily on 'Hydration' as the core benefit. While consistent, this is a generic commodity claim that exposes you to price wars.
truth_4.why_matters: Being consistent is good, but being consistently generic is fatal. If your strongest link is 'Hydration,' you are competing with Vaseline, not La Mer.
truth_4.the_hard_choice: Your highest alignment is on 'Hydration,' which is the most crowded and commoditized claim in skincare. You are consistently telling a boring story. You must decide: either break this consistency to inject a proprietary 'benefit twist' that risks alignment but adds value (Option A), or double down on 'Hydration' and fight a war of attrition on price (Option B). Consistency on a weak claim is just consistently invisible.

truth_5.headline: Sterile vs. Lived-In
truth_5.gap_description: While both territories align on 'The Purist,' the PDP visual execution includes more context (bottles on shelves, hands applying). This 'messier' reality is likely driving the conversion on Amazon.
truth_5.evidence: Visual Identity: PDP 3/5 (User Context) vs WWW 4/5 (Lab Context)
truth_5.why_matters: The 'drift' in visual execution on PDP towards lifestyle imagery is actually a strength. It proves customers want to see the product in use, not just on a pedestal.
truth_5.the_hard_choice: Your website looks like a laboratory (Sterile), while your Amazon page looks like a bathroom (Lived-In). The Amazon approach is less 'premium' but more 'human,' and it's working. You have a choice: either sanitize the Amazon imagery to protect the clinical brand equity (Option A), or contaminate the website with 'Real Life' photography to drive conversion (Option B). Perfection is pretty, but reality pays the bills.

marker_1.so_what: WWW sells a dream of age reversal; PDP sells a tool for dry skin. The 'why' is lost in translation.

marker_2.so_what: WWW aims to 'Redefine Beauty Standards'; PDP just wants to 'Help you get through the day'. The scale of ambition is mismatched.

marker_3.so_what: WWW values 'Precision' and 'Science'; PDP values 'Safety' and 'Gentleness'. One is aggressive, the other is defensive.

marker_4.so_what: The single most damaging gap. WWW positions as 'Clinical Luxury'; PDP as a 'Commodity Staple'. This destroys price elasticity.

marker_5.so_what: WWW acts like a detached 'Dermatologist' (Cool); PDP acts like a 'Mommy Blogger' (Warm). The consumer doesn't know who is talking.

marker_6.so_what: Complete psychological break. WWW is 'The Sage/Magician' (Power); PDP is 'The Caregiver' (Service). You are confusing authority with servitude.

marker_7.so_what: WWW is formal and scientific. PDP is chatty and colloquial. This dilutes the 'Clinical' authority you claim on the site.

marker_8.so_what: Both channels maintain a 'Clean' aesthetic, though WWW is more 'Lab-like' and PDP is more 'Lifestyle'. This is a passable foundation.

marker_9.so_what: WWW talks about 'Cellular Renewal' (Complex); PDP talks about 'Soft Skin' (Simple). You are dumbing down the product too much on Amazon.

marker_10.so_what: The story shifts from a scientific breakthrough (WWW) to a morning chore (PDP).

marker_11.so_what: You are selling the ingredients on your site and the texture on Amazon. Customers buy the benefit, not the feature list.

marker_12.so_what: Your USP on WWW is 'Patented Technology'; on PDP it is 'Bundle Pricing'. This destroys the perception of luxury.

marker_13.so_what: Both channels focus on results, but WWW is about 'Long-term Health' while PDP is about 'Instant Feel'.

marker_14.so_what: This is your anchor. Both channels agree the product hydrates effectively. Leverage this consistency.

marker_15.so_what: Both channels promise confidence, but WWW leans slightly more into 'Status' while PDP leans into 'Comfort'.

marker_16.so_what: WWW tries to be 'Radiant' and 'Glowy' (High Energy), PDP is 'Clean' and 'Simple' (Low Energy).

marker_17.so_what: WWW signals exclusivity (The Elite); PDP signals inclusivity (The Family). You cannot be both a club and a public park.
